# Epic: Track and Trace Functionality

## Functional Requirement: Shipment Tracking

### User Story 1: Track Shipment Status from Order Details

**As a** customer,
**I want** to view the shipment status from my order details page,
**so that** I don't have to leave the webshop or enter a tracking code manually.

#### Implementation Hints:
1. Leverage the Python Requests library or Django's inbuilt HTTP client to communicate with the third-party shipping API.
2. Create a model in Django ORM linking orders to shipment details, including tracking codes.
3. Develop a Django view that fetches the shipment status for an order and presents it in the order details page.

### User Story 2: Handle Multiple Shipments per Order

**As a** customer,
**I want** to see all shipments related to an order, even if my order is split into multiple shipments,
**so that** I can track each shipment individually.

#### Implementation Hints:
1. Extend the Django ORM model to accommodate multiple tracking codes per order.
2. Update the Django view to handle multiple shipment statuses.
3. Implement appropriate UX on the order details page to show the status of multiple shipments without confusion.

## Functional Requirement: Return Shipments

### User Story 3: Initiate Return Process

**As a** customer,
**I want** to be able to initiate a return from my order details page,
**so that** I can conveniently start the return process.

#### Implementation Hints:
1. Create a 'Return' button or link on the order details page.
2. Set up a Django view to handle the initiation of return shipments, communicating with the third-party shipping API as necessary.
3. Add a new status in the database for return shipments.

### User Story 4: Track Return Shipment Status

**As a** customer,
**I want** to track the status of my return shipment from the order details page,
**so that** I know when the return shipment has been received by the webshop.

#### Implementation Hints:
1. Leverage the third-party shipping API to fetch the status of return shipments.
2. Create a Django ORM model to link return shipments to orders and track their status.
3. Update the order details page to show the status of return shipments.

### User Story 5: Handle Multiple Return Shipments per Order and Consolidated Return Shipments

**As a** customer,
**I want** to see all return shipments related to an order and consolidate multiple orders in a single return shipment,
**so that** I can conveniently manage return shipments.

#### Implementation Hints:
1. Extend the Django ORM model to handle multiple return shipments per order and consolidated return shipments.
2. Update the Django view to handle these scenarios.
3. Update the UX to allow customers to select multiple orders for a consolidated return shipment.

## Definition of Done

- [ ] Shipment statuses are accurately fetched from the third-party shipping API and displayed on the order details page.
- [ ] Multiple shipments per order are supported and their statuses are displayed correctly.
- [ ] Return process can be initiated from the order details page.
- [ ] Statuses of return shipments are accurately displayed on the order details page.
- [ ] Multiple return shipments per order and consolidated return shipments are handled correctly.
- [ ] All new functionality works on all supported browsers and devices.
- [ ] New functionality is covered by automated tests.
- [ ] All code changes have been reviewed and approved.
- [ ] The deployment plan has been reviewed and approved.
- [ ] The feature has been deployed to production and verified by the Product Owner.
can you create mermaid flowcharts?

Mermaid is a markdown-like syntax that allows you to generate diagrams and flowcharts with text in a way similar to markdown. Although I, as a text-based AI model, can generate the text that represents a flowchart in Mermaid syntax, I don't have the capability to actually render the diagram itself.

Here's a simple flowchart using Mermaid syntax:

```mermaid
graph TB
    A[Start] --> B{Is it working?}
    B -->|Yes| C[Great!]
    B -->|No| D[Fix it.]
    D --> B
```

In this diagram:

1. `A[Start]` represents a node with the label "Start".
2. `-->` represents an arrow pointing from one node to another.
3. `B{Is it working?}` represents a decision node with the label "Is it working?".
4. `B -->|Yes| C[Great!]` and `B -->|No| D[Fix it.]` represent conditional arrows with labels "Yes" and "No" leading from the decision node to other nodes.

You would paste this Mermaid syntax into a tool that supports rendering Mermaid diagrams to visualize the actual flowchart. For instance, tools like Visual Studio Code with Mermaid plugin, Mermaid Live Editor, or Markdown renderers with Mermaid support could be used.

Please note that Mermaid syntax may be different depending on the version you are using, so it is always good to refer to the documentation of the specific version you have. As of my last training cut-off in September 2021, the above syntax should be valid for creating a flowchart.

Please can you generate a number of Mermaid flowcharts that implement the following functional specification?

## Original Requirements:

### Magic link

1. User receives magic link after being inactive or requesting one
2. Magic link allows user to continue where they have left off
3. Magic link after "completed order" shows a message saying "order has been submitted. You {will/have} received an order confirmation. Please contact us for changes" (V1)
4. Magic link expires after 7 days after which a renewed link needs to be send to the same communication channel. This gets triggered automatically


## Analysis:

This issue encompasses the development and implementation of the Magic Link feature for our webshop. The purpose of this feature is to allow users to continue with their incomplete orders from a unique link sent to them. 

The following features need to be developed:

### Magic Link Generation

Generate magic links that redirect users to their specific (incomplete) orders.
- Utilize a token generator library for creating unique, single-use tokens for each order.
- Using the token, generate a unique URL for an order, and have it ready to send it to the customer
- Use the Magic Link Security from the next section to sign the link to protect it from tampering
- Incomplete orders get directed to a webshop page where de order process can be continued
- Complete orders get directed to a notification page stating that the order has already been submitted and contact information for making changes.
- Magic link renewal: magic links that are still relevant after 7 days should be detected, and a new token and magic link should be generated and send to the contact via the prefered communication channels.
- An order can have multiple magic links, and all but the most recent should be considered expired. If any such link is used, the user should be redirected to the latest link (or even better a new link, while expiring the old link!)

### Magic Link Security

Ensure that the magic links are secure and resistant to any form of exploitation.

- Hint: [Signing is part of Django Core functionality](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.2/topics/signing/), though may need some customization.
- Sign the tokens or the entire link URL with a server secret to affirm their authenticity: `signed = signing.dumps({"foo": "bar"})`. 
- Provide a signature validation algorithm: `value = signing.loads(signed)` - If the signature has been altered in any way, a django.core.signing.BadSignature exception will be raised.

### Magic Link Expiration

Set the magic links to expire after a specific time period (7 days).
- Integrate an expiration time within the token, or cross-verify the token against a database of expired tokens.
- If the order is still relevant, regenerate a magic link and send it.

### Invalid/Expired Magic Link Handling

Handle scenarios where the magic link is either expired or invalid.
- Verify the token when used, and display an error page with a clear message if it's invalid.

### Magic Link Webshop Entry

Re-enter the webshop with this session state to continue the order process
- Determine the Order from the magic link
- Fill the session state from the Order persistent storage

I want you to act as a software requirements engineer for a webshop that is developed in Python/Django. The webshop rents out payment terminals that you can order for a certain period of time.  I will describe a feature at a global system level, and you will write a GitHub Epic with multiple single line functional requirements that can easily be implemented and validated. After all the requirements, you will give a Definition of Done with checkboxes. You should use markdown format for readability.
The feature I want to develop is as follows:

For legal reasons called 'Wwft' it is required for the webshop to keep track of who the Ultimate Beneficial Owners 'UBOs' are from business customers (there can be at most 4 of them).
If we can determine the 'UBOs' from querying the Chamber of Commerce API, with a user provided company id, that is a good option.
Otherwise, we will have to ask the customer to fill in this information via a form.
Alternatively, we can provide the form for download, and the customer has to fill it in and upload a filled in and signed version.
For each of the UBOs, we need to store Initials, Last name, Date of Birth, Place of Birth, Nationality, and Gender.
The customer that submits or changes this information has to formally sign with Name, Function, Date, Signature.
We may need a validation mechanism to verify the identity of the customer.
This validation should include validation of the (Digital?) signature, for instance with a service like 'Onfido' 
We can store the information for recurring customers for their next order.
We should ask the recurring customers if the 'UBOs' information is still correct.
The input forms may need to be localized to different countries.

# Epic: Ultimate Beneficial Owners (UBOs) Identification and Storage

## Functional Requirements

### Authentication & Authorization

- **FR1.1:** User must be authenticated before submitting UBOs information.
    - _Hint:_ Use Django's built-in authentication middleware for user authentication.

- **FR1.2:** Only authenticated customers can submit or change UBOs information.
    - _Hint:_ Implement role-based access control for authorization.

### Data Collection

- **FR2.1:** System should be able to collect UBOs information from Chamber of Commerce API by using company id.
    - _Hint:_ Use Python's requests library to query the API. 

- **FR2.2:** If API query fails, system should be able to collect UBOs information via a form.
    - _Hint:_ Create Django form for UBOs information collection.

- **FR2.3:** Provide an option for customers to download a form, fill it in, and upload the signed version.
    - _Hint:_ Use Django's FileField for upload field. Ensure validation for appropriate file types.

- **FR2.4:** UBOs form should collect Initials, Last name, Date of Birth, Place of Birth, Nationality, and Gender for each UBO.
    - _Hint:_ Django ModelForm could be used for this functionality.

- **FR2.5:** Any submission or change of UBOs information requires formal signing with Name, Function, Date, Signature.
    - _Hint:_ Include these fields in the form.

### Data Validation

- **FR3.1:** Implement validation mechanism to verify the identity of the customer.
    - _Hint:_ Consider integrating with an Identity verification API.

- **FR3.2:** Implement validation of the digital signature, for instance with a service like 'Onfido'.
    - _Hint:_ Integrate with the Onfido API for signature verification.

### Data Storage and Retrieval

- **FR4.1:** System should store UBOs information for recurring customers.
    - _Hint:_ Use Django models to save UBOs information in the database.

- **FR4.2:** For recurring customers, ask whether the UBOs information is still correct.
    - _Hint:_ Provide a UI prompt or modal for confirmation during the checkout process.

### Internationalization

- **FR5.1:** Input forms need to be localized to different countries.
    - _Hint:_ Django provides a framework for internationalization. Use that for form localization.

## Definition of Done

- [ ] The feature fulfills all the functional requirements listed above.
- [ ] All code changes are properly documented.
- [ ] Code is written following the coding standards and style guide.
- [ ] Code is reviewed and approved by at least one other team member.
- [ ] All code changes are covered by unit tests.
- [ ] All unit tests pass and the coverage is at least 80%.
- [ ] The feature is tested with end-to-end tests.
- [ ] The feature is deployed to a staging environment and tested.
- [ ] The feature has been demoed to the product owner and received approval.
- [ ] The feature is merged to the main branch and deployed to production.
- [ ] The feature does not introduce new bugs in the system.
- [ ] The feature is monitored for at least one week and no issues are reported.
Please provide an Introduction and Rationale that in a few lines describe what we want to achieve and why we need to achieve it.

# Introduction

The purpose of this Epic is to design and implement a system within our webshop for identification and tracking of Ultimate Beneficial Owners (UBOs) of our business customers. The system will be able to extract the UBOs information from the Chamber of Commerce API or collect it directly from the customers via a form. This information will then be stored for recurring customers. 

# Rationale

The implementation of this feature is necessary for two primary reasons. 

1. **Regulatory Compliance:** Legal provisions called 'Wwft' necessitate us to know who the UBOs of our business customers are, thus making this feature a regulatory requirement. 

2. **Customer Convenience:** By storing this information for recurring customers, we eliminate the need for customers to repeatedly provide the same data, thereby enhancing their user experience. Furthermore, the possibility to localize the input forms improves accessibility for customers from different countries.

The successful implementation of this feature will ensure regulatory compliance, improve customer experience, and potentially attract a wider customer base.
Does the less than operator < work for django datetime isoformat?

Django is a Python web framework, and the ISO format is a standard way of representing dates and times as strings. If you have two datetime objects, you can indeed use the less than (`<`) operator to compare them.

However, if you're asking whether you can use the `<` operator to directly compare two datetime strings in ISO format, the answer is yes and no. 

This operation will perform a lexicographic (dictionary order) comparison of the strings. This means it will compare the strings character by character from left to right. This can work in some cases because the ISO format is designed in a way where the most significant parts (year, month, day, hour, minute, second) are arranged from left to right. 

```python
"2023-01-01T12:00:00" < "2023-01-02T12:00:00"  # returns True
```

However, this might not work as expected when the datetime strings are not zero-padded or if they contain timezone information.

In Django, if you're comparing datetime fields, it's better to let the database do the comparison, or convert the strings to datetime objects and then compare them.

```python
from django.utils.dateparse import parse_datetime

datetime1 = parse_datetime("2023-01-01T12:00:00")
datetime2 = parse_datetime("2023-01-02T12:00:00")

if datetime1 < datetime2:
    ...
```

In a Django QuerySet filter, you can use the `__lt`, `__lte`, `__gt`, `__gte` lookup types to compare datetime fields.

```python
from datetime import datetime

now = datetime.now()

MyModel.objects.filter(date_field__lt=now)  # get objects where date_field is less than now
```
how do I run django tests via 'manage.py'  in visual studio code

To run Django tests via 'manage.py' in Visual Studio Code, you'll need to use the integrated terminal and a launch configuration.

1. **Open the Integrated Terminal**

In Visual Studio Code, open the integrated terminal by selecting `View > Terminal` from the menu or by pressing `Ctrl+`` (backtick) on your keyboard.

2. **Navigate to Your Project Directory**

In the terminal, navigate to the directory of your Django project. You can do this by typing `cd path_to_your_project_directory` and pressing `Enter`. Replace `path_to_your_project_directory` with the actual path to your Django project directory.

3. **Run Django Tests**

Once you're in your Django project directory, you can run Django tests by typing `python manage.py test` in the terminal and pressing `Enter`.

If you want to run tests for a specific Django app, you can do so by appending the name of the app to the `test` command. For example, if you have a Django app named `my_app`, you can run tests for this app by typing `python manage.py test my_app` in the terminal and pressing `Enter`.

Additionally, if you would like to automate this process using a launch configuration:

1. **Open or Create a launch.json File**

In Visual Studio Code, open the Run view by selecting `Run > Open Configurations` from the menu. If your workspace doesn't already have a launch.json file, Visual Studio Code will create one for you.

2. **Add a New Launch Configuration**

In your launch.json file, add a new launch configuration for running Django tests. Here is an example of what this configuration might look like:

```json
{
    "name": "Python: Django Tests",
    "type": "python",
    "request": "launch",
    "program": "${workspaceFolder}/manage.py",
    "args": [
        "test",
        "my_app"
    ],
    "django": true
}
```

Replace `"my_app"` with the name of the Django app you want to test, or remove it entirely to run tests for all apps.

3. **Run Your New Launch Configuration**

You can now run Django tests by selecting `Run > Start Debugging` from the menu, or by pressing `F5` on your keyboard. Make sure your new launch configuration is selected in the Run view before you start debugging.
can I use pytest to do this via an extension?

Yes, you can use PyTest to run your Django tests in Visual Studio Code (VS Code) with the help of the Python extension.

To do this, you need to follow these steps:

1. **Install the Python Extension**

Firstly, you'll need to install the Python extension for Visual Studio Code. This can be done by searching for 'Python' in the Extensions view (`Ctrl+Shift+X`).

2. **Install PyTest**

PyTest is a Python testing framework that can be used to write simple, scalable tests quickly. You can install it using pip:

```sh
pip install pytest
```

3. **Configure PyTest for Django**

PyTest needs a little configuration to work with Django. First, you need to install the pytest-django plugin:

```sh
pip install pytest-django
```

Then, create a pytest.ini or pyproject.toml file in your project root and add the following:

For pytest.ini:

```ini
[pytest]
DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE = yourproject.settings
python_files = tests.py test_*.py *_tests.py
```

For pyproject.toml:

```toml
[tool.pytest.ini_options]
DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE = "yourproject.settings"
python_files = ["tests.py", "test_*.py", "*_tests.py"]
```

Replace `yourproject.settings` with the import path for your actual Django settings module.

4. **Configure PyTest in Visual Studio Code**

In your VS Code settings (`Ctrl+,`), you need to tell the Python extension to use PyTest for testing. You can do this by setting `"python.testing.pytestEnabled"` to `true` and `"python.testing.unittestEnabled"` to `false`. If you're working in a specific workspace, you can put these settings in .vscode/settings.json in your project directory:

```json
{
    "python.testing.pytestEnabled": true,
    "python.testing.unittestEnabled": false
}
```

5. **Run Tests**

Once PyTest is set up and configured in VS Code, you can run your tests. You can do this by opening the Test view (`Ctrl+Shift+T`) and clicking the 'Run All Tests' button, or by right-clicking on a specific test and clicking 'Run Test'.

Make sure your test files match the pattern specified in the `python_files` setting of your pytest.ini or pyproject.toml file. PyTest will automatically discover these files and any test functions or methods they contain.

Remember, VS Code's Python extension supports running, debugging, and displaying test results directly in the Test Explorer UI. You should see a beaker icon on the activity bar on the side. If you click on it, you'll see all your tests and can run/debug them individually or as a group.
in django with pytest, how do I check if a request to an url gives the expected http response?

In Django with PyTest, you can use Django's test client to make requests to your application and check the HTTP responses. 

Here's an example on how you can test that a GET request to a URL returns the expected HTTP status code.

Let's assume you have an endpoint at '/my-url/' which should return a HTTP 200 status code when a GET request is made.

1. Create a test file (for instance, `test_views.py`) in your Django app's directory. In this file, you will write your test. 

2. Import the required modules and write your test function:

```python
import pytest
from django.urls import reverse
from django.test import Client

@pytest.mark.django_db  # Mark it to use the Django test database
def test_my_url():
    client = Client()
    response = client.get(reverse('my_url_name'))  # Use the url name defined in your urls.py
    assert response.status_code == 200
```

This code creates a Django test client, makes a GET request to '/my-url/', and then checks that the response has a status code of 200.

Remember to replace `'my_url_name'` with the name of the URL you're testing. The `reverse` function will convert this URL name to a URL path.

Also, the `@pytest.mark.django_db` decorator is necessary if the view you're testing interacts with the database. If your view doesn't interact with the database, you can remove this decorator.

3. Now you can run your test using PyTest. 

Open the terminal in VS Code (`View > Terminal`), navigate to the directory containing `manage.py`, and type `pytest` to run your test.

The output will show whether the test passed or failed. If the test failed, the output will include information about why the test failed.
how do I return a HTTP response to indicate a bad signature from django.core.signing?

If you're working with Django's signing functionality and want to return a specific HTTP response when a signature doesn't match (a "Bad Signature" error), you can do it by handling the `django.core.signing.BadSignature` exception. Here's an example:

```python
from django.core import signing
from django.http import HttpResponseBadRequest

def your_view(request):
    signer = signing.Signer()
    try:
        original = signer.unsign(request.GET.get('signed_value'))
        # If the signature matches, you can continue processing.
        # For example, you might return an HttpResponse.
    except signing.BadSignature:
        # If the signature doesn't match, you can return a
        # 400 Bad Request response or any other HTTP response.
        return HttpResponseBadRequest("Bad Signature")
```

In this example, if the `signer.unsign()` call cannot validate the signature, it raises a `BadSignature` exception. By catching this exception, you can return a 400 Bad Request response. 

Remember, it's crucial to ensure that you don't leak sensitive information through error messages in production environments. The "Bad Signature" message in this example is very generic and doesn't give away specifics about why the error occurred, which is usually a good practice for security reasons.
In Excel, How do I sum the values of column 'F', when the 'G' column equals cell $A2?

You can use the SUMIF function in Excel to accomplish this. The SUMIF function allows you to add up cells in a range that meet certain criteria.

The syntax for the SUMIF function is `SUMIF(range, criteria, [sum_range])`.

- `range` is the range of cells that you want to apply the criteria against.
- `criteria` is the criteria in the form of a number, expression, cell reference, or text that defines which cells will be added.
- `sum_range` is optional. It's the cells that will be added; if this parameter is omitted, `range` will be used.

For your specific example, if you want to sum the values in column 'F' where the corresponding value in column 'G' equals the value in cell $A2, you could use the following formula:

```excel
=SUMIF(G:G, $A$2, F:F)
```

Here's what it does:

- `G:G` is the range that we want to apply our criteria against. This includes all cells in column 'G'.
- `$A$2` is our criteria. We want to find cells in column 'G' that are equal to the value in cell $A2.
- `F:F` is the range that will be summed, but only for rows where the criteria for column 'G' was true. This includes all cells in column 'F'.

Just make sure to replace `G:G`, `$A$2`, and `F:F` with your actual column letters and cell references if they are different.
Can you explain how PHP Smarty works? Especially how the Controller keep track of global variables like $ARGS and $GLOBALS via session management?

Smarty is a template engine for PHP, which is widely used to separate the business logic from its presentation. In other words, Smarty allows PHP developers to deal with the PHP code separate from the HTML code. It achieves this by the use of templates, which contain placeholders for content.

Let's break down some concepts in relation to your question.

1. **Controller**: In a MVC (Model-View-Controller) context, the Controller is a component that handles user input and updates the model and view accordingly. It is not specific to Smarty, but a general concept used in software design.

2. **$ARGS**: This doesn't appear to be a standard PHP or Smarty global variable. It might be used in a particular project as a way to pass variables from the Controller to the View, but its usage could be specific to that project. In a typical Smarty implementation, you'd use `$smarty->assign('name', $value);` to assign a variable to the template.

3. **$GLOBALS**: This is a PHP superglobal array, which contains all globally scope variables. It's available in all scopes throughout a script. You can use this to share data among different parts of a PHP application, but it is generally recommended to limit its usage due to potential issues with side-effects and testing.

4. **Session Management**: Sessions in PHP allow you to preserve certain data across subsequent accesses. A session creates a file in a temporary directory on the server where registered session variables and their values are stored. This data will be available to all pages on the site during that visit. A session ends when the user closes the browser, or after leaving the site, the server will terminate the session after a predetermined period of time, commonly 30 minutes duration.

In a typical PHP/Smarty application, the Controller would handle user input, perform any necessary actions or calculations using Models, and then assign variables to the View using the Smarty `assign` method.

To store variables across multiple requests, you would typically use PHP's `$_SESSION` superglobal, not `$GLOBALS`. You could assign a session variable in your controller like so:

```php
$_SESSION['myVariable'] = $someValue;
```

And then access this in a later request, again in your controller:

```php
$someValue = $_SESSION['myVariable'];
```

Once you've retrieved your session data, you can assign it to your Smarty template using the `assign` method:

```php
$smarty->assign('name', $someValue);
```

In the template, you can then access it with `{$name}`.

Note that you need to call `session_start()` at the beginning of your PHP script before you can use `$_SESSION`. Also, make sure to manage sessions securely, such as regenerating session IDs on login, to prevent session hijacking or fixation.

can I inspect the session object of a PHP Smarty website in the browser?

Session data in PHP is stored on the server, and only a reference to the session, typically a session ID, is stored in the client's browser (usually within a cookie). Therefore, you can't directly inspect PHP session data from the browser as you can with client-side storage mechanisms like cookies, Local Storage, or Session Storage. However, there are indirect ways to inspect PHP session data: 1. **Debugging Output**: You could modify the PHP code to output session data to the page for debugging purposes. Be cautious with this approach as you don't want to accidentally expose sensitive data. It's also a good idea to ensure that such debugging information can only be enabled in a safe, local development environment. Here's an example of how you might output all session data: ```php echo '
';
    var_dump($_SESSION);
    echo '
'; ``` 2. **Browser Developer Tools**: While you can't see the actual session data, you can see the session cookie that contains the session ID in the browser's Developer Tools. In Chrome, for example, you can go to the "Application" tab and find the cookie under the "Cookies" section. This ID is used by PHP to identify the session data on the server. 3. **Logging**: Another method is to write session data to a log file on the server whenever a page is loaded. However, similar to the debugging output, make sure not to expose sensitive information and restrict access to these log files. An example would be: ```php error_log(print_r($_SESSION, true)); ``` 4. **Debugging Tools**: There are debugging tools available such as Xdebug for PHP that can give you a lot of insight into what your PHP code is doing, including inspection of session data. This would require you to setup the debugging environment. Remember, exposing session data should only be done for debugging and development purposes, and in a secure environment. You should never expose session data to end users as it can contain sensitive information.

How do I identify an incomplete order? It could have some timeout, but what is reasonable? It could also have been replace by a newer order from the same customer.

Determining when an order is considered incomplete can indeed be a challenging task and depends on the specific business model, industry standards, and customer behavior. There isn't a one-size-fits-all approach, but here are a few strategies to consider:

**Timeout-based strategy:** 
You could determine a period of inactivity after which an order is marked as incomplete. The length of this timeout could be based on data about your users' behavior. For instance, if users typically complete orders within 15 minutes of adding the first item to their cart, a 30-minute timeout might be reasonable. Be sure to communicate this clearly to your users so that they understand when and why their orders may be timed out.

**Newer Order Strategy:**
If a new order is placed by the same customer, you could consider the previous order as incomplete. This may be appropriate in certain business contexts, but not all. Consider your users' typical purchasing behavior and whether or not they might reasonably be expected to place multiple orders simultaneously.

**Mixed Strategy:**
You might also combine these strategies. For example, you could use a timeout-based strategy by default, but also consider an order incomplete if a new order is placed by the same customer before the timeout has elapsed.

**Explicit User Action:**
Another way could be by providing a "Save for Later" option. If a customer chooses this, the order is marked as incomplete.

Remember that it's also important to consider user experience. Frequent notifications about incomplete orders can be perceived as spammy or pushy. Strike a balance between encouraging users to complete their orders and respecting their time and attention. Also, consider the legal and privacy implications of tracking and using this kind of user data.
Does django have a session timeout event?

As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, Django does not provide a built-in session timeout event that you can hook into. Django sessions are based on cookies, and session data is stored server-side (in database, file, or cache depending on your session engine). The expiration of the session is controlled by the setting `SESSION_COOKIE_AGE`, which defaults to 2 weeks.

However, when a session expires, Django does not trigger a specific event. Instead, if you attempt to access session data for an expired session, Django behaves as if the session data does not exist.

If you need to run some code when a session expires, you might have to handle it in a different way. One possible approach is to use Django's middleware to check the age of the session on each request, and if it's past your timeout, run your custom logic. However, please note that this will not be triggered if the user simply closes their browser and never sends another request.

Another approach could be using a periodic task (with something like Celery) to clean up expired sessions and execute your logic when an expired session is detected.

Remember that specific implementation may vary depending on Django's updates after September 2021. Always refer to the most recent Django documentation for the best practice.

In Django, where and how would I implement magic link creation, including a cryptographic signature, and magic link validation?

In Django, implementing magic link creation and validation would typically involve several components, including views, URL routing, and a cryptographic library. I will give an example of how you could accomplish this using Django's built-in cryptographic signing functionality.

**1. Magic Link Creation**

Django includes a signing module that you can use to securely sign data. In this case, you can use it to sign the ID of an order, and then include this signed ID in a URL. Here's a simple example of how you can do that in a view:

```python
from django.core import signing

def create_magic_link(order_id):
    signed_id = signing.dumps(order_id)
    # Now create a URL that includes this signed ID
    magic_link = 'https://your-webshop.com/complete_order/' + signed_id
    return magic_link
```

In this code, `signing.dumps()` both signs and serializes the order ID, converting it to a string that can be included in a URL.

**2. Magic Link Validation**

You can then create a view that deserializes and validates a signed order ID, and allows the user to complete their order. Here's an example:

```python
from django.core import signing
from django.http import HttpResponseBadRequest

def complete_order(request, signed_order_id):
    try:
        order_id = signing.loads(signed_order_id)
        # Now retrieve the order and allow the user to complete it
        # (You'll have to fill in this part based on your own code)
    except signing.BadSignature:
        return HttpResponseBadRequest("Invalid or expired link")
```

In your `urls.py`, you'd have something like this to route the URLs correctly:

```python
from django.urls import path
from . import views

urlpatterns = [
    path('complete_order/<str:signed_order_id>/', views.complete_order, name='complete_order'),
    # Other URL patterns...
]
```

This way, the `signed_order_id` from the URL will be passed to your `complete_order` view. The `signing.loads()` function will check the signature and raise a `BadSignature` exception if it's invalid, which you can catch and return an error message.

Please note that this is a simplified example and there are additional concerns that you would need to address in a production environment, such as secure delivery of the magic link, ensuring the user who clicks the link is the user who created the order, etc. Also, remember to handle all edge cases such as non-existent order_id or already completed orders.

I get double // when I do:
        url = reverse('links:magic_view', kwargs={'magic': signed_value})

The `reverse()` function in Django is used to create a URL from a named URL pattern. If you're seeing double `//` in your generated URL, it could mean there is a trailing slash in your URL pattern definition or an extra leading slash in your `kwargs` values.

However, from the example you've provided, it doesn't seem like there would be an extra `/` from the `reverse` call.

A possible source of double slashes could be when you're joining the base URL with the path returned from the `reverse` function. Here is an example of what not to do:

```python
base_url = 'https://example.com/'
path = reverse('links:magic_view', kwargs={'magic': signed_value})
full_url = base_url + path  # This could result in 'https://example.com//path/'
```

The `base_url` variable has a trailing slash, and `reverse` will also return a leading slash, so concatenating these would result in a double slash.

To fix this, ensure that there's only one slash between the base URL and the path. Here's one way to do it:

```python
base_url = 'https://example.com'
path = reverse('links:magic_view', kwargs={'magic': signed_value})
full_url = base_url + path  # 'https://example.com/path/'
```

Another way is to use the Python standard library function `urllib.parse.urljoin`, which should handle these edge cases for you:

```python
from urllib.parse import urljoin

base_url = 'https://example.com/'
path = reverse('links:magic_view', kwargs={'magic': signed_value})
full_url = urljoin(base_url, path.lstrip('/'))  # 'https://example.com/path/'
```

This code removes the leading slash from the path before joining it with the base URL, ensuring that there's only one slash between the base URL and the path.

how do I make a django model field read only? E.g. it should be set at construction, and can not be modified.

To make a Django model field read-only (i.e., it can be set at construction but can't be modified later), you can override the `save` method of the model. This method is called whenever you save an instance of the model, so you can use it to prevent certain fields from being changed after the instance has been created.

Here is an example using an `OrderMagicLink` model, where we want to make the `order` field read-only:

```python
from django.db import models

class Order(models.Model):
    # Your order fields here
    pass

class OrderMagicLink(models.Model):
    order = models.ForeignKey(
        Order,
        on_delete=models.CASCADE,
    )
    # other fields...

    def save(self, *args, **kwargs):
        if self.pk is not None:  # if the instance is already saved
            original = OrderMagicLink.objects.get(pk=self.pk)
            if self.order != original.order:
                raise ValueError("The 'order' field cannot be changed.")
        super().save(*args, **kwargs)
```

In the `save` method of the `OrderMagicLink` model:

- `if self.pk is not None`: This checks if the instance has already been saved to the database. `pk` is the primary key of the instance, and it is `None` if the instance has not been saved yet.
- `original = OrderMagicLink.objects.get(pk=self.pk)`: If the instance has been saved, we get the original instance from the database.
- `if self.order != original.order`: This checks if the `order` field has been changed.
- `raise ValueError("The 'order' field cannot be changed.")`: If the `order` field has been changed, we raise a `ValueError`.

This way, if you try to change the `order` field of an `OrderMagicLink` instance and save it, you will get a `ValueError`.

Remember to add a similar check for any other fields you want to be read-only. 

This pattern is commonly used for fields that should not be changed once the object has been created, but it is not enforced at the database level. Anyone with raw access to the database could still change the field. If you need to enforce this at the database level, you might need a different solution, such as creating a custom database constraint, but this is more complex and depends on your specific database system.

Can I also use django core signing to obscure or encrypt the message?

Yes, Django provides the `django.core.signing` module that you can use to sign and/or encrypt data. It can be especially useful to obscure or encrypt data that you're sending to the user (e.g., in a cookie or a URL) and to verify that the data hasn't been tampered with when it comes back.

Here's a basic example of how you can use `django.core.signing` to sign a string:

```python
from django.core import signing

value = "Hello, world!"
signed_value = signing.dumps(value)

try:
    original_value = signing.loads(signed_value)
except signing.BadSignature:
    print("Data was tampered with.")
else:
    print(original_value)  # "Hello, world!"
```

In this code:

- `signing.dumps(value)` signs the string and returns a URL-safe string that includes the original data followed by a signature. You can use this signed value safely in a URL, a cookie, etc.
- `signing.loads(signed_value)` checks the signature of the signed value and returns the original data. If the data was tampered with, it raises a `signing.BadSignature` exception.

If you want to encrypt the data as well as sign it, you can use the `signing.encrypt()` and `signing.decrypt()` functions instead of `signing.dumps()` and `signing.loads()`. These functions use symmetric encryption, meaning that the same key is used to encrypt and decrypt the data.

However, please note that while signing can help ensure data integrity (i.e., that the data hasn't been tampered with), it doesn't hide the data. If you need to keep the data secret, you should use encryption (or use signing and encryption together).
encrypt does not seem part of signing?

I apologize for the confusion, but as of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, Django's `django.core.signing` module does not include an encryption feature. It provides a way to sign values, ensuring data integrity by checking that the data hasn't been tampered with, but it does not provide a way to encrypt and decrypt values.

If you need to encrypt data in your Django application, you'll have to use a different tool or library. For instance, the Python `cryptography` library provides a wide range of cryptographic recipes including symmetric encryption.

If you're storing sensitive information in your models, you might consider using a package like django-encrypted-model-fields, which provides field classes that automatically encrypt and decrypt their data.

Here's an example of how you can use the `cryptography` library to encrypt and decrypt a message:

```python
from cryptography.fernet import Fernet

# Generate a key and create a cipher using this key
key = Fernet.generate_key()
cipher = Fernet(key)

# Encrypt a message
message = b"Hello, world!"
encrypted_message = cipher.encrypt(message)
print(encrypted_message)

# Decrypt the message
decrypted_message = cipher.decrypt(encrypted_message)
print(decrypted_message)  # b"Hello, world!"
```

In this code:

- `Fernet.generate_key()` generates a new key that you can use to create a Fernet cipher.
- `Fernet(key)` creates a new Fernet cipher using this key.
- `cipher.encrypt(message)` encrypts the message using this cipher.
- `cipher.decrypt(encrypted_message)` decrypts the encrypted message.

Please note that this is a simple example and may not be suitable for all use cases. Always make sure to follow best practices for cryptographic security in your specific context.
Can I use the Django SECRET_KEY for Fernet?

Yes, you can use the Django `SECRET_KEY` for encryption and decryption with `Fernet` from the `cryptography` library, but there are some considerations:

1. `Fernet` expects the key to be 32 url-safe base64-encoded bytes. This translates to 44 bytes of data. Django's `SECRET_KEY` is usually a 50-byte long random string, which may not be compatible as it is. You'll need to transform it in a compatible format.

2. Django `SECRET_KEY` is used for various security-related operations in Django (like signing cookies and tokens), so using it for additional purposes increases the potential impact if the key is ever compromised. It's generally best to use separate keys for separate purposes.

3. Exposing the `SECRET_KEY` can lead to serious security implications, so it should be handled carefully.

Here's an example of how you could use Django's `SECRET_KEY` to create a Fernet key:

```python
from cryptography.fernet import Fernet
from django.conf import settings
import base64
import hashlib

# Get Django's SECRET_KEY
secret_key = settings.SECRET_KEY

# Create a 32 bytes long key by hashing the SECRET_KEY
fernet_key = base64.urlsafe_b64encode(hashlib.sha256(secret_key.encode()).digest())

cipher = Fernet(fernet_key)

# Now you can use `cipher` to encrypt and decrypt messages
```

This code takes Django's `SECRET_KEY`, hashes it to get a 32-byte string, and then base64 encodes that string to get a Fernet-compatible key. The resulting key is then used to create a `Fernet` object, which can be used for encryption and decryption. 

Remember, be very careful with how you handle keys in a production environment. It's a good practice to rotate them periodically and keep them out of your source code (e.g., by using environment variables or a secure key management system). Also, consider if using a separate key for this purpose is more suitable for your application.
Is Fernet cipher idempotent? E.g. encrypting the same message twice, will it give the same result?

No, encryption using `Fernet` from the `cryptography` library is not idempotent. This means if you encrypt the same message multiple times, you will not get the same encrypted output each time.

This is because `Fernet` implements symmetric key cryptography using AES in CBC mode with PKCS7 padding, which introduces an initialization vector (IV) for each encryption operation. This IV is randomly generated and ensures that the encrypted output is different each time you encrypt the same message, even with the same key. This property enhances security by making the encrypted data less predictable.

Here's a simple demonstration:

```python
from cryptography.fernet import Fernet

# Generate a key
key = Fernet.generate_key()
cipher = Fernet(key)

# Encrypt the same message twice
message = b"Hello, world!"
encrypted_message1 = cipher.encrypt(message)
encrypted_message2 = cipher.encrypt(message)

print(encrypted_message1)
print(encrypted_message2)
print(encrypted_message1 == encrypted_message2)  # This will output False
```

In this script, the same message is encrypted twice with the same cipher (and therefore the same key), and the resulting encrypted messages are different.
how do I encrypt a json object, I think I need to encode it to binary first?

Yes, in order to encrypt a JSON object, you first need to convert it into a string (via `json.dumps()`) and then encode that string to bytes. Then, you can proceed to encrypt the bytes.

Here's an example:

```python
import json
from cryptography.fernet import Fernet

# Generate a key
key = Fernet.generate_key()
cipher = Fernet(key)

# Define a JSON object
data = {
    "name": "John Doe",
    "age": 30,
    "city": "New York"
}

# Convert JSON to string and then encode to bytes
data_str = json.dumps(data)
data_bytes = data_str.encode()

# Encrypt the bytes
encrypted_data = cipher.encrypt(data_bytes)
print(encrypted_data)

# Decrypt the bytes
decrypted_data = cipher.decrypt(encrypted_data)

# Decode bytes to string and then convert string to JSON
decrypted_data_str = decrypted_data.decode()
decrypted_data_json = json.loads(decrypted_data_str)

print(decrypted_data_json)
```

In this code:

- `json.dumps(data)` converts the JSON object to a string.
- `data_str.encode()` converts the string to bytes, which is needed for the `encrypt()` method.
- `cipher.encrypt(data_bytes)` encrypts the data.
- `cipher.decrypt(encrypted_data)` decrypts the data back to its original form.
- `decrypted_data.decode()` decodes the bytes back into a string.
- `json.loads(decrypted_data_str)` converts the string back into a JSON object.
In order to allow non-dict objects to be serialized set the safe parameter to False.

The `safe` parameter you mentioned is used with the `json.dumps()` function in Python, specifically when you're trying to serialize an object that is not a dictionary. By default, `json.dumps()` will only accept a dictionary. If you try to pass anything else, you will receive a `TypeError`.

However, if you're serializing simple data types (like strings, integers, lists, or tuples) or JSON serializable objects, you can use `json.dumps()` without setting `safe` to `False`. The `safe` parameter is typically used with Django's `JsonResponse` to enable non-dictionary objects.

Here's an example:

```python
import json

# Define a list
data = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# Convert list to JSON
data_json = json.dumps(data)

print(data_json)  # Output: "[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]"
```

In this example, `json.dumps()` is used to convert a list to a JSON-formatted string.

If you're working with Django's `JsonResponse` and want to serialize non-dictionary objects, you can set `safe=False`:

```python
from django.http import JsonResponse

# Define a list
data = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# Return a JsonResponse with a list
return JsonResponse(data, safe=False)
```

In this Django example, `JsonResponse` is used to return a JSON response containing a list. By setting `safe=False`, you're telling Django that it's okay to serialize non-dictionary objects.
does json.loads understand binary?

No, `json.loads()` does not understand binary data. It expects a string (or more precisely, a JSON formatted string) as input. 

If you have binary data, you would need to decode it into a string before passing it to `json.loads()`. The encoding used for decoding would depend on how the binary data was originally encoded. Often, UTF-8 is used for this purpose.

Here's an example:

```python
import json

# Assuming binary_data is your binary data
binary_data = b'{"name": "John", "age": 30}'

# Decode the binary data into a string
decoded_data = binary_data.decode('utf-8')

# Now you can use json.loads() to parse the JSON
data = json.loads(decoded_data)

print(data)  # Output: {'name': 'John', 'age': 30}
```

In this example, `decode('utf-8')` is used to decode the binary data into a string, and then `json.loads()` is used to parse the JSON string into a Python dictionary. 

Remember, the exact decoding method needed will depend on how the binary data was originally encoded. If it was not originally encoded as a UTF-8 string, you may need to use a different decoding method.

I get a django database migration:
            field=models.DateTimeField(default=datetime.datetime(2023, 6, 9, 11, 22, 50, 667129, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)),

but I want the default to be the current datetime + 7 days, is that possible?

Yes, it is possible to set the default value of a `DateTimeField` to be the current date/time plus 7 days. In Django, you can use the `timezone` module for this. 

The `default` argument to a field can take a callable, which will be called each time a new object is created. So you can create a function that returns the current date/time plus 7 days, and pass that function as the `default` argument.

Here's how you can do it:

```python
from django.db import models
from django.utils import timezone
import datetime

def seven_days_from_now():
    return timezone.now() + datetime.timedelta(days=7)

class OrderMagicLink(models.Model):
    expiration_date = models.DateTimeField(default=seven_days_from_now)
    # ...
```

In this code, `seven_days_from_now()` is a function that returns the current date/time plus 7 days. This function is passed as the `default` argument to `expiration_date`.

Note that `seven_days_from_now` is passed without parentheses. This is because you're passing the function itself to be called each time a new `OrderMagicLink` object is created, not the result of calling the function once when the field is defined.

I have django tests that run ok locally, but raise an error in GitHub CI/CD:

  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/cryptography/utils.py", line 30, in _check_bytes
    raise TypeError("*** must be bytes".format(name))
TypeError: token must be bytes

What can be the problem and how do I solve it?

The error message you're seeing is stating that the value you're passing as a `token` is not a byte string. In Python, byte strings are indicated with a `b` prefix, like `b"my string"`.

There are a couple of reasons why you might be seeing this error only on GitHub CI/CD and not on your local machine:

1. **Different Python versions**: Your local machine and the GitHub CI/CD environment may be running different versions of Python, which may handle certain data types or function calls differently.

2. **Different package versions**: The versions of your dependencies (e.g., the `cryptography` package) may differ between your local environment and the CI/CD environment. If the CI/CD environment has an older version of a package, it might not support all the same features as the newer version you're using locally.

To resolve this issue, you can try the following:

1. **Ensure consistency of Python versions**: Make sure that you're using the same Python version in your GitHub CI/CD environment as you are locally.

2. **Ensure consistency of package versions**: If you're using a `requirements.txt` file or a `Pipfile` to manage your Python dependencies, make sure you include the versions of each package, and that these are installed in the CI/CD environment.

3. **Check your inputs**: Make sure that the value you're passing as `token` is indeed a byte string. If it's a regular string, you can convert it to bytes with the `encode()` method, like `"my string".encode()`. 

Without more context about your specific CI/CD setup and your Django application, it's hard to give more specific advice. But these are general solutions that often help with this type of problem.
how do I convert an object that is str | bytes to bytes?

You can write a function that checks if the object is a string or bytes. If it's a string, you can encode it into bytes. If it's already bytes, you can just return the object as it is. Here's a simple way to do this:

```python
def to_bytes(obj):
    if isinstance(obj, str):
        return obj.encode()
    elif isinstance(obj, bytes):
        return obj
    else:
        raise TypeError("Object must be str or bytes")

# Examples
str_obj = "hello"
bytes_obj = b"hello"

print(to_bytes(str_obj))  # b'hello'
print(to_bytes(bytes_obj))  # b'hello'
```

In this function, `isinstance(obj, str)` checks if `obj` is a string and `isinstance(obj, bytes)` checks if `obj` is bytes. If the object is a string, `obj.encode()` converts the string into bytes. If the object is not a string or bytes, the function raises a `TypeError`.

You can use this function to ensure that the inputs to your `cryptography` functions are always bytes, which should help avoid the `TypeError` you're seeing in your GitHub CI/CD tests.

In Django, if I render a template with a context, how can I make sure that the new page also knows the context?
E.g. I have page1.html that is rendered with context1, and I want to have a link to page2.html, where the GET request processing in Django knows context1

When you navigate from one page to another (i.e., from `page1.html` to `page2.html` in your case), the context data is not automatically passed along because HTTP is stateless. However, there are several ways to pass data between views in Django. 1. **Using Query Parameters**: You can add the data as query parameters in the URL to the next page. Then, you can use `request.GET` in the view that handles `page2.html` to retrieve the data. For instance, if you're linking to the second page like this: ```html Go to Page 2 ``` You can retrieve these in the view for `page2.html` like this: ```python def view_for_page2(request): param1 = request.GET.get('param1', default_value) param2 = request.GET.get('param2', default_value) # ... ``` This method is simple and works well for small amounts of data, but it's not suitable for sensitive or large amounts of data. 2. **Using Django Sessions**: Django has built-in support for sessions, which allow you to store data that is preserved across subsequent requests. You can add data to the session in the view for `page1.html`, then retrieve it in the view for `page2.html`. Here's an example of setting session data: ```python def view_for_page1(request): request.session['key'] = 'value' # ... ``` And retrieving it: ```python def view_for_page2(request): value = request.session.get('key', default_value) # ... ``` This method works well for larger amounts of data and is more secure than using query parameters, but it relies on cookies and requires that the user has not disabled them in their browser. 3. **Using Form Submissions**: If the data that needs to be passed is the result of a form submission on `page1.html`, you can also handle the form submission in the view for `page2.html` and use the submitted data there. If the form method is POST, you can retrieve the data like this: ```python def view_for_page2(request): if request.method == 'POST': param1 = request.POST.get('param1', default_value) param2 = request.POST.get('param2', default_value) # ... ``` If the form method is GET, you can retrieve the data in the same way as in the first method: ```python def view_for_page2(request): param1 = request.GET.get('param1', default_value) param2 = request.GET.get('param2', default_value) # ... ``` Remember that you must always sanitize and validate any data that comes from the user before using it in your application to avoid potential security issues like SQL injection or cross-site scripting (XSS).

Error response from daemon: Ports are not available: exposing port TCP 127.0.0.1:3306 -> 0.0.0.0:0: listen tcp 127.0.0.1:3306: bind: An attempt was made to access a socket in a way forbidden by its access permissions.

The error message you're seeing suggests that you're trying to bind to port 3306 (a common port for MySQL), but you don't have permission to do so or something else is already using that port. There are a couple of things you might try:

1. **Check if the port is in use**: You can do this by using `netstat` command if you're on a Unix-like system (like Linux or MacOS) or `Get-NetTCPConnection` in PowerShell if you're on Windows. 

   - Unix-like systems: Open a terminal and type `sudo netstat -tuln | grep :3306`
   - Windows: Open a PowerShell and type `Get-NetTCPConnection | ? LocalPort -eq 3306`

   If you see any output from those commands, that means something else is already using port 3306.

2. **Change the port**: If the port is in use and you can't stop the process that's using it, you might try using a different port. For instance, if you're running a Docker command that looks like this:

   ```
   docker run -p 3306:3306 -d some-mysql
   ```
   You might change it to something like:

   ```
   docker run -p 3307:3306 -d some-mysql
   ```
   In this example, your application will need to connect to MySQL on port 3307.

3. **Run with elevated permissions**: If the port is not in use and you still can't bind to it, you might try running the command with elevated permissions. For example, on a Unix-like system, you might prepend the command with `sudo`.

   ```
   sudo docker run -p 3306:3306 -d some-mysql
   ```

Remember to replace `some-mysql` with the actual image you are trying to run.
In GitHub, is there some way to fill the Wiki with the source code tree?

GitHub Wikis are designed to be a place where you can share long-form content about your project, such as how to use it, how to contribute, or the design principles behind it. They are not designed to automatically reflect the source code tree of your project.

However, you can manually create a structure in your Wiki that mirrors your source code tree. You can create a new page for each directory and file, and then link them together to create a navigable structure. This would require manual updating whenever your source code tree changes.

If you want to automatically generate documentation from your source code, you might want to look into tools designed for that purpose. For example, Doxygen can generate documentation from source code for many programming languages. You can then host this documentation on a GitHub Pages site associated with your repository.

Alternatively, you could consider using a code browsing tool or a more advanced documentation system that integrates directly with GitHub and can reflect the structure of your source code. Examples of such tools include Sourcegraph for code browsing and Read the Docs for documentation.

Remember that the best approach depends on your specific needs and the nature of your project.

title: Django Model Filled with Random Data

parts: python code to fill django model items with pseudo random data

Filling Django model items with pseudo-random data can be accomplished using the `Faker` library. `Faker` is a Python package that generates fake data. Here's how you could use it with a Django model:

First, install the `Faker` library by running this command in your terminal:
```
pip install faker
```

Next, here's an example Python script that fills a Django model with pseudo-random data:

```python
from django.core.management.base import BaseCommand
from faker import Faker
from yourapp.models import YourModel

class Command(BaseCommand):
    help = 'Fills database with random data'

    def handle(self, *args, **options):
        fake = Faker()

        for _ in range(100):  # creates 100 instances
            YourModel.objects.create(
                field1=fake.name(),
                field2=fake.address(),
                field3=fake.text(),
                # Continue for each field in your model
            )

        self.stdout.write(self.style.SUCCESS('Successfully filled database with random data'))
```
Replace `YourModel` with the name of your Django model and `field1`, `field2`, `field3`, etc. with the names of the fields in your model. Also replace `yourapp` with the name of your Django app where your model resides. 

You can run this script by creating a custom Django management command. Create a new directory `management/commands` in one of your Django app directories, and then save this script as a `.py` file inside the `commands` directory. You can then run the script with the following command in your terminal:

```
python manage.py [your_script_name]
```

Remember to replace `[your_script_name]` with the name of your Python script.

Note that the `Faker` library generates different kinds of data depending on the method you call on it. For example, `fake.name()` generates a name, `fake.address()` generates an address, and so on. You can find the full list of `Faker` methods in the [Faker documentation](https://faker.readthedocs.io/). 

Make sure you pick the `Faker` method that generates data of the correct type for each of your model fields. For example, if a field in your model is a `DateField`, you should use `fake.date()` to generate a date for it.

# 【229†How to Get the Transcript of a YouTube Video】

[Image]  【230†Joe Fedewa】

[Image]Joe Fedewa   
Staff Writer   

Joe Fedewa is a Staff Writer at How-To Geek. He has been covering consumer technology for over a decade and previously worked as Managing Editor at XDA-Developers. Joe loves all things technology and is also an avid DIYer at heart. He has written thousands of articles, hundreds of tutorials, and dozens of reviews. 【230†Read more...】

【231†About How-To Geek】

【232†@tallshmo†twitter.com】   

Updated Nov 4, 2022, 3:00 pm EDT | 1 min read    

[Image: YouTube logo.]

To get the transcript for a YouTube video on a desktop browser, open the YouTube video, click on the three dots below the video title, and then click "Show Transcript." On an iPhone, iPad, or Android device, tap the downward-facing arrow next to the title, then tap "Show Transcript."

【233†Closed captions】 are a handy feature on YouTube, but they only appear in real-time along with the video. You can get a transcript of those captions to read at your own speed. It works on desktops, iPhones, and Android. 

The full transcript of a YouTube video can be useful for a variety of reasons. You can avoid manually transcribing quotes by copying the direct text. It’s also handy to be able to 【234†search】 for specific words or parts of the video by text.

Table of Contents

> 【235†How to Get YouTube Transcripts on Desktop】  
> 【236†How to Get YouTube Transcripts on iPhone and Android】  
> 

## How to Get YouTube Transcripts on Desktop

On a desktop or laptop, head on over to 【237†YouTube.com†www.youtube.com】 in a web browser such as Google Chrome and open a video to watch.

[Image: Select a video.]

Next, click the three-dot menu icon underneath the title of the video.

[Image]

Select “Show Transcript” from the menu.

[Image: Select "Show Transcript."]

The transcript box will open and you’ll see the captions listed along with timestamps. You can click a caption to jump to that part of the video.

[Image: Select caption to jump to timestamp.]

Lastly, at the bottom of the transcript box, you can switch between the available languages.

[Image: Switch languages.]

## How to Get YouTube Transcripts on iPhone and Android

To get a transcript on mobile, open the YouTube app on your 【238†iPhone†apps.apple.com】, 【238†iPad†apps.apple.com】, or 【239†Android†redirect.viglink.com】 device and select a video to watch.

[Image: Choose video to watch.]

Next, tap the down arrow on the right side of the video title.

[Image: Tap the down arrow.]

The video description will appear along with a “Show Transcript” button, tap it.

[Image: Tap "Show Transcript" button.]

The captions will appear in a box listed along with timestamps. You can tap a caption to jump to that part of the video.

[Image: Select caption to jump to timestamp.]

Tap the three-dot menu icon to switch between the available languages.

[Image: Switch between languages.]

That’s it! This is one of those 【240†lesser-known YouTube features】 that can be really handy in certain situations. It’s a 【241†nice trick to know】 about.

# How to Get the Transcript of a YouTube Video

[Image]  Joe Fedewa

[Image]Joe Fedewa   
Staff Writer   

Joe Fedewa is a Staff Writer at How-To Geek. He has been covering consumer technology for over a decade and previously worked as Managing Editor at XDA-Developers. Joe loves all things technology and is also an avid DIYer at heart. He has written thousands of articles, hundreds of tutorials, and dozens of reviews. Read more...

About How-To Geek

@tallshmo   

Updated Nov 4, 2022, 3:00 pm EDT | 1 min read    

[Image: YouTube logo.]

To get the transcript for a YouTube video on a desktop browser, open the YouTube video, click on the three dots below the video title, and then click "Show Transcript." On an iPhone, iPad, or Android device, tap the downward-facing arrow next to the title, then tap "Show Transcript."

Closed captions are a handy feature on YouTube, but they only appear in real-time along with the video. You can get a transcript of those captions to read at your own speed. It works on desktops, iPhones, and Android. 

The full transcript of a YouTube video can be useful for a variety of reasons. You can avoid manually transcribing quotes by copying the direct text. It’s also handy to be able to search for specific words or parts of the video by text.

Table of Contents

> How to Get YouTube Transcripts on Desktop  
> How to Get YouTube Transcripts on iPhone and Android  
> 

## How to Get YouTube Transcripts on Desktop

On a desktop or laptop, head on over to YouTube.com in a web browser such as Google Chrome and open a video to watch.

[Image: Select a video.]

Next, click the three-dot menu icon underneath the title of the video.

[Image]

Select “Show Transcript” from the menu.

[Image: Select "Show Transcript."]

The transcript box will open and you’ll see the captions listed along with timestamps. You can click a caption to jump to that part of the video.

[Image: Select caption to jump to timestamp.]

Lastly, at the bottom of the transcript box, you can switch between the available languages.

[Image: Switch languages.]

## How to Get YouTube Transcripts on iPhone and Android

To get a transcript on mobile, open the YouTube app on your iPhone, iPad, or Android device and select a video to watch.

[Image: Choose video to watch.]

Next, tap the down arrow on the right side of the video title.

[Image: Tap the down arrow.]

The video description will appear along with a “Show Transcript” button, tap it.

[Image: Tap "Show Transcript" button.]

The captions will appear in a box listed along with timestamps. You can tap a caption to jump to that part of the video.

[Image: Select caption to jump to timestamp.]

Tap the three-dot menu icon to switch between the available languages.

[Image: Switch between languages.]

That’s it! This is one of those lesser-known YouTube features that can be really handy in certain situations. It’s a nice trick to know about.

RELATED: PSA: Double-tap YouTube with 2 Fingers to Skip Chapters

parts:
Apologies, but as an AI model developed by OpenAI, I am currently unable to directly watch or interact with video or audio content. This means that I cannot directly watch a YouTube video or listen to its audio. However, I can try to retrieve a transcript of the video if it's available. In the case of this video, it appears I'm not able to access the transcript directly.

The method for retrieving YouTube transcripts is generally as follows:

On a desktop or laptop:
1. Navigate to YouTube.com in a web browser.
2. Open the video you want to watch.
3. Click the three-dot menu icon underneath the title of the video.
4. Select “Show Transcript” from the menu.
5. The transcript box will open, and you’ll see the captions listed along with timestamps. You can click a caption to jump to that part of the video.
6. At the bottom of the transcript box, you can switch between the available languages【12†source】【13†source】.

On an iPhone, iPad, or Android device:
1. Open the YouTube app.
2. Select a video to watch.
3. Tap the downward-facing arrow next to the title.
4. Tap "Show Transcript."
5. The captions will appear in a box listed along with timestamps. You can tap a caption to jump to that part of the video.
6. Tap the three-dot menu icon to switch between the available languages【11†source】.

If a transcript isn't available for the video, or if the method above isn't working, it's possible that the video's creator hasn't enabled transcripts or closed captions for the video.

parts:
Ik wil dat je handelt als belastingadviseur, voor zowel aangifte BTW als inkomstenbelasting.
Als ik met een fiscaal probleem kom, dan geeft je me uitleg over het probleem, en gaat voor mij op zoek op het internet naar de meest recente belastingregels, bij voorkeur van officiele informatiebronnen als de belastingdienst website. Dat vat je samen in een aantal korte regels waaraan ik als belastingplichtige moet voldoen. Daarbij geef je links van de websites waar je de informatie gevonden hebt.

Het eerste probleem waar ik mee zit:

Ik ben zorgverlener, en een deel van mijn inkomen krijg ik van de SVB op mijn rekening gestort, zonder dat ik een factuur hoef te sturen. Deze inkomsten zijn vrijgesteld van BTW.
Mijn vragen:
1. moet ik dit aangeven in de BTW aangifte en zo ja hoe?
2. moet ik dit aangeven in de aangifte inkomstenbelasting, en zo ja hoe?

# Btw-aangifte doen en betalen

U doet btw-aangifte per maand, kwartaal of jaar. Zorg ervoor dat u uw aangifte en betaling op tijd doet. Hier leest u waar u op moet letten als u aangifte doet.

## Btw-aangifte: waar moet u aan denken?

Als ondernemer voor de btw moet u btw-aangifte doen. U geeft in uw aangifte de btw aan die u hebt berekend aan uw klanten, en de btw die u kunt aftrekken.

【29†Lees verder over...】

## Fiscaal vertegenwoordiger 

Buitenlandse ondernemer kunnen zelf aan zijn administratieve verplichtingen voor de Nederlandse btw voldoen. Maar zij mogen dit ook overlaten aan een fiscaal vertegenwoordiger. In een aantal situaties is dit zelfs verplicht.

【30†Lees verder over...】

## Btw-aangifte: welke, wanneer en hoe?

U doet digitaal aangifte. Waar moet u op letten bij uw 1e aangifte? En de laatste aangifte van het jaar?

【31†Lees verder over...】

## Bij uw btw-aangifte berekenen hoeveel u moet betalen of terugkrijgt 

U berekent bij uw aangifte zelf hoeveel btw u aan ons moet betalen. In uw administratie houdt u bij hoeveel btw u hebt berekend aan klanten en hoeveel btw u hebt betaald aan leveranciers. Het verschil hiertussen is de btw die u moet betalen of die u terugkrijgt.

【32†Lees verder over...】

## Btw betalen of terugkrijgen 

Nadat u de aangifte hebt ingevuld, ziet u in uw aangifte het bedrag dat u aan btw moet betalen of dat u terugkrijgt. U krijgt geen aanslag, maar u moet het btw-bedrag zelf aan ons overmaken.

【33†Lees verder over...】

## Btw-aangifte betalen met iDEAL via Mijn Belastingdienst Zakelijk 

Doet u btw-aangifte via Mijn Belastingdienst Zakelijk? Dan kunt u uw aangifte na insturen direct met iDEAL betalen. U vindt hiervoor in Mijn Belastingdienst Zakelijk – bij de ingestuurde aangifte – een betaallink.

【34†Lees verder over...】

## Boetes voor te laat aangifte doen of betalen van btw 

Hebt u uw aangifte niet of te laat ingediend? Of hebt u te laat, niet of te weinig betaald? Dan kunt u een boete krijgen.

【35†Lees verder over...】

## Btw-aangifte corrigeren 

Toch een vergissing gemaakt in uw aangifte? Te veel of juist te weinig btw betaald? Corrigeer de aangifte met behulp van het suppletieformulier.

【36†Lees verder over...】

## Btw-fraude: voorkom dat u erbij betrokken raakt, let op de signalen 

Hoe voorkomt u dat u betrokken raakt bij btw-fraude? Zorg dat u uw handelsrelatie kent en let op signalen die kunnen wijzen op btw-fraude.

【37†Lees verder over...】

# Btw-aangifte doen en betalen

U doet btw-aangifte per maand, kwartaal of jaar. Zorg ervoor dat u uw aangifte en betaling op tijd doet. Hier leest u waar u op moet letten als u aangifte doet.

## Btw-aangifte: waar moet u aan denken?

Als ondernemer voor de btw moet u btw-aangifte doen. U geeft in uw aangifte de btw aan die u hebt berekend aan uw klanten, en de btw die u kunt aftrekken.

Lees verder over...

## Fiscaal vertegenwoordiger 

Buitenlandse ondernemer kunnen zelf aan zijn administratieve verplichtingen voor de Nederlandse btw voldoen. Maar zij mogen dit ook overlaten aan een fiscaal vertegenwoordiger. In een aantal situaties is dit zelfs verplicht.

Lees verder over...

## Btw-aangifte: welke, wanneer en hoe?

U doet digitaal aangifte. Waar moet u op letten bij uw 1e aangifte? En de laatste aangifte van het jaar?

Lees verder over...

## Bij uw btw-aangifte berekenen hoeveel u moet betalen of terugkrijgt 

U berekent bij uw aangifte zelf hoeveel btw u aan ons moet betalen. In uw administratie houdt u bij hoeveel btw u hebt berekend aan klanten en hoeveel btw u hebt betaald aan leveranciers. Het verschil hiertussen is de btw die u moet betalen of die u terugkrijgt.

Lees verder over...

## Btw betalen of terugkrijgen 

Nadat u de aangifte hebt ingevuld, ziet u in uw aangifte het bedrag dat u aan btw moet betalen of dat u terugkrijgt. U krijgt geen aanslag, maar u moet het btw-bedrag zelf aan ons overmaken.

Lees verder over...

## Btw-aangifte betalen met iDEAL via Mijn Belastingdienst Zakelijk 

Doet u btw-aangifte via Mijn Belastingdienst Zakelijk? Dan kunt u uw aangifte na insturen direct met iDEAL betalen. U vindt hiervoor in Mijn Belastingdienst Zakelijk – bij de ingestuurde aangifte – een betaallink.

Lees verder over...

## Boetes voor te laat aangifte doen of betalen van btw 

Hebt u uw aangifte niet of te laat ingediend? Of hebt u te laat, niet of te weinig betaald? Dan kunt u een boete krijgen.

Lees verder over...

## Btw-aangifte corrigeren 

Toch een vergissing gemaakt in uw aangifte? Te veel of juist te weinig btw betaald? Corrigeer de aangifte met behulp van het suppletieformulier.

Lees verder over...

## Btw-fraude: voorkom dat u erbij betrokken raakt, let op de signalen 

Hoe voorkomt u dat u betrokken raakt bij btw-fraude? Zorg dat u uw handelsrelatie kent en let op signalen die kunnen wijzen op btw-fraude.

Lees verder over...

# Tarieven en vrijstellingen

Welk btw-tarief berekent u aan uw klanten? Het algemene btw-tarief is 21%. Voor sommige goederen en diensten geldt het lage tarief van 9%, het 0%-tarief of een vrijstelling. Controleer hier welk tarief u moet hanteren.

## Goederen en diensten met 21% btw 

Het 21%-tarief geldt voor alle goederen en diensten die niet vrijgesteld zijn, en die niet onder het 9%-tarief of het 0%-tarief vallen. 

【27†Lees verder over...】

## Goederen met 9% btw 

Voor een beperkt aantal goederen mag u het verlaagde tarief van 9% toepassen.

【28†Lees verder over...】

## Diensten met 9% btw 

Levert u diensten? Dan brengt u btw in rekening. Het verlaagde tarief van 9% geldt voor een aantal diensten.

【29†Lees verder over...】

## Goederen met 0% btw 

Als u goederen levert aan het buitenland of opslaat in een douane-entrepot, gebruikt u meestal het 0%-tarief. Dit houdt in dat u op de factuur vermeldt dat het 0%-tarief is toegepast.

【30†Lees verder over...】

## Diensten met 0% btw 

Het 0%-tarief geldt voor een aantal diensten waarbij sprake is van grensoverschrijdende activiteiten, zoals personenvervoer met een vliegtuig of zeeschip van of naar bestemmingen buiten Nederland. 

【31†Lees verder over...】

## Vrijstellingen van btw 

Zijn uw goederen en diensten vrijgesteld? Of moet u btw in rekening brengen? In een aantal branches en voor een aantal activiteiten bent u vrijgesteld van btw. 

【32†Lees verder over...】

## Toelichting btw-tarief na vragen 

Soms wordt de tarieftoepassing van bepaalde goederen of diensten nader bekeken. Dat gebeurt als daar vragen over zijn. 

【33†Lees verder over...】

# Vrijstellingen van btw

Zijn uw leveringen van goederen en diensten vrijgesteld? Of moet u btw in rekening brengen? In een aantal branches en voor een aantal activiteiten bent u vrijgesteld van btw. U brengt dan geen btw in rekening.

Let op!

Onderstaande vrijstellingen gelden ook voor de invoer van goederen uit niet-EU-landen en voor 【49†intracommunautaire verwervingen】.

## Wat moet u doen?

Administratie bijhouden? Btw aftrekken over kosten? Als u vrijgesteld bent, hebt u te maken met andere btw-regels. U leest hier 【16†wat u moet doen als u vrijgestelde goederen of diensten levert】.
